conclusion: Understanding the scenario of a plank leaning against a smooth vertical wall with a block at the lower right.
Description of the plank and block with given masses and friction coefficient.
Two forces applied to the block: horizontal force F1 and vertical force F2.
Goal is to find the condition F1 must satisfy to make the plank move upward.
Drawing a free-body diagram to visualize forces on the block and plank.
Calculating gravity force on the block: 8 N downward.
Identifying normal force from the plank on the block.
Calculating friction force from the plank on the block: 0.2 N.
Observation that the wall is smooth, implying no friction between plank and wall.
Considering normal force from the wall on the plank due to its leaning position.
Considering the angle between the plank and the horizontal due to its leaning position.
Description of the plank's position and the block's location at the lower right corner.
Observation of the plank's position against the wall and the block's location.
Observation of the diagram with labels indicating directions of F1 and F2.
Observation of the plank's vertical position and block attachment in the diagram.
Reiteration of plank length, mass, and block mass with friction coefficient.
